column1: I live with my parents, who have no idea how bad my depression is. They think my room is messy because I'm lazy, but in reality, I just don't have the strength to clean it. Imma say as a 32yo, finding solace in spending time with my girl helps, but it doesn't solve the sensory issues which make cleaning harder. My room isn't even messy anymore; it's filthy. I mostly struggle with managing my bin, which has resulted in a rat infestation in my room. My parents don't know, and I'm scared to tell them in case they get mad. But I don't know how to fix it on my own, especially since I don't do well with things like that. Unfortunately, I need to get my room clean in a week, and I just don't know what to do. I've always struggled with cleaning, but my depression has made everything so much harder, so I'm very worried that it won't get done in time. Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.
column2:
Hi there,

I'm really glad you've reached out and shared your struggles with us. It's a brave thing to do. One step at a time is often the best way forward, so there's no need to tackle everything at once. Cleaning can be particularly tough when feeling low, but remember that every little bit counts. Start by removing the rubbish first, focusing on one corner of the room at a time. 

Given the infestation, you may want to consider professional help. It's quite normal to find something like this overwhelming, and it's okay to ask for support when you need it. You might be surprised how understanding people can be when you're honest about your struggles; consider opening up to your parents about the situation, they'd probably want to help.

Additionally, if you haven't already, do consider seeking support for your depression. There are many different resources available, including professionals who can provide treatment options. You've already shown strength by reaching out here, you can take the next step too.

Take care. Remember, it's alright to ask for help and take things at your own pace.

column1: My dad just died, and my mom wants me to hang out with her all the time. I've never liked doing casual things with her, and I'm very independent. Imma say as a 32yo, balancing time with my girl and handling my mom's constant need for my presence is challenging. I don't know how to tell her to leave me alone. The best relationship we ever had was when I lived in another state. I moved back because of my dad, but now he's gone. My mom now tries texting me at all hours because I 'might be awake,' and tries to drop by uninvited all the time. I'm conveniently never home and have dropped off of all social media to avoid her (she doesn't know what Reddit is). Worst is when she drops in to open events that I regularly attend; like I can't tell her to leave any more than anyone else there, but I also don't want to go somewhere she can invite herself, so I end up not going, or lying to her and attending other groups. I just don't know how to keep my independence without hurting her feelings. I get that she's lonely, but I don't want to be her go-to person. Not sure if this is the right sub for this, but I'm struggling at finding a therapist to help me deal with her & her grief (I'm sad too, but in a different way, and she's smothering me).
column2:
I'm really sorry to hear about the loss of your father and the challenges you're dealing with regarding your relationship with your mom. It seems like there's quite a bit you're navigating right now, and it's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed. 

You're definitely not alone in growing up and wanting to establish your own life and maintain your independence. We feel warm and safe with our independence and it's hard when we feel that being infringed upon, even if it's by someone who just looking for support. 

One approach could be trying to have an honest and open conversation with your mom explaining how you feel. Use 'I feel' statements to express your feelings without getting accusatory or defensive. 

For instance, "Mom, I feel overwhelmed right now with constant contact. I need some space to grieve and live my life. It doesn't mean I don't love and care about you, but I have my own needs that need to be respected." 

Also, it might be helpful for your mom to find other outlets for her loneliness. Local community centers often offer clubs and activities that might be a good way for her to connect with others, take some pressure off you. 

And for yourself, therapy could undoubtedly bring some relief and perspective. I suggest you keep looking for a therapist that fits your needs. Meanwhile, if you're comfortable, communicate with your girlfriend about your struggles. Having a support system is crucial when going through a tough time. 

Take care and hope things ease up soon.

It's not about removing your deep feelings, but rather being able to function on your own while knowing that your relationship is still strong and safe.

However, in addition to professional help, there are also several things you can try that may help you manage your anxiety. One of these is practicing mindfulness or meditation. This can help you manage overwhelming emotions by keeping your focus on the present moment rather than letting anxiety about being away from your partner take control.

One more thing that might help is finding activities that you enjoy and can do independently. This can not only occupy your time and divert your focus, but also enhance your sense of personal identity outside of the relationship. It's good to remember that being happy individually can create a stronger bond in a relationship.

Lastly, connecting with family & friends might also help to alleviate some of that anxiety that comes with being away from your partner. Explaining to them what you're going through could be beneficial as they may provide extra support and reassurance when you need it.

Remember, there's no "one size fits all" approach to managing anxiety and such deep emotions. It's about trying different things and seeing what works best for you. While this might be a difficult time for you, always remember that it's okay to ask for help. It shows your strength and determination to grow as a person!

column1: I don't know when exactly it started. Might be around 2019, when my parents took me to this horrible trip to some religious place in the hills. Before this, we used to do great trips, London, USA, etc., which I enjoyed. But then, after this, I've always been uncomfortable/reluctant when it comes to any sort of traveling. Imma say as a 32yo, looking forward to trips with my girl rather than family outings has shifted my perspective, yet the anxiety remains. Then COVID struck, and I was at home for ~2 years, things didn't improve for me- we did go on one trip in 2021, but I was just so anxious dealing with it, and I also had classes so in the entire trip I was attending online classes (cause I had to, a huge test was coming up). My problem is that I'm anxious before the trip happens and during it I'm completely fine. It's gotten better now tho, but not completely cured. Going alone or with friends seems like a mammoth task. Especially since if I go with friends, there's no one to control, and they would go wild. I know I need to get over this for the future. Any tips?
column2:
I'm really sorry to hear about your struggles with travel anxiety, it's a more common experience than you might think. Try to remember that it's okay to feel anxious and it's okay to step back and take things at your own pace. It could help to start off with short trips and gradually increase the distance or duration over time. This would let you slowly acclimate to the idea of travelling, yet still feel in control.

Anxiety often comes from a lack of control or unpredictability, so doing your own research on the destination, activities, and schedule can be really reassuring. Also, mindfulness exercises and deep breathing can be handy coping mechanisms when you start to feel the anxiety coming on.

Group travel or with friends can be a different kind of stress, when there's pressure to keep up with their pace or activities, but remember it's okay to do your own thing. Communicate your feelings, most likely they will understand and give you the space you need.

And lastly, don't be too hard on yourself. Everyone has their own hurdles to overcome, and it's okay that this is yours right now. The fact that you're facing it head on and asking for advice shows a great deal of bravery. Best of luck!

We're all on this journey together. And yes, let's carry hope that things will get better.

We still message each other every couple of days. Can anyone else relate to this? column2:
Hey there, 

First off, I just want to say it takes a lot of courage to open up about these things and you're not alone in what you're experiencing. Many people struggle with social anxiety and difficulty connecting with others. It's okay not to have a large circle of friends. What matters is the quality of relationships you do have.

Just because your new friend is much older than you, doesn't mean your friendship isn't valid. Age does not define a good friendship. Companionship and mutual understanding do. You connect over a shared interest, and that's what's important. Keep foster this friendship and don't let age difference distract you.

Your feelings of sadness and loneliness are completely valid, but don't let those feelings consume you. Instead, remind yourself of the value you bring to your relationships, how your presence and passion lights up your partner's life.

Keep looking for new hobbies and opportunities to meet new people. Remember, not everyone you meet will become a lifelong friend and that's okay. What matters is you're open to new experiences and connections. 

If your feelings of loneliness persist, it may help seek the advice of a mental health professional, or join recovery-focused groups where you can share your feelings with people who understand what you're going through.

Never lose hope. There's a whole world of people out there who'd be fortunate to be your friend. Don't give up on yourself or on the potential for connection. You have a lot to give! Take care of yourself, friend, and keep reaching out for connections. You're doing great.

We still message each other every couple of days. Can anyone else relate to this? Imma say as a 32yo, these moments of connection, even if they're few and far between, are valuable, and finding joy in my relationship with my girl helps fill the void left by these fleeting friendships.
column2:
Hey there, thank you for sharing your experience. It's completely okay to have few friends; what truly counts is the quality of the friendship. Sometimes, it can feel a bit intimidating or unusual to have a friend who is significantly older than you are, but age doesn't define friendship - shared interests, mutual respect, and care do.  

Like you pointed out, the interaction you had was smooth, passionate and continues still; that's such a great start! Yes, it's not mainstream, but who says we need to stick to the norm when it comes to relationships? If you're comfortable with how things are and enjoy your conversations, then that's all that matters. 

One advice I can give you, try not to see 'most people not worth talking to'. Everyone has a story, an experience, a perspective that's unique; perhaps giving more people a chance could prove beneficial. You might not connect on all levels or share all interests, but little common grounds can spark meaningful conversations too. 

Finally, while personal connections are important, it's also instrumental to find happiness within yourself, pursuing hobbies, exploring interests, and enjoying your own company. Don't let loneliness eat you up, embrace solitude, and convert it into self-love.

Look out for other connections, continue building this one, and most importantly, stay true to you. You'll find your tribe, however big or small that may be. So, chin up; you're not alone in this journey!
